prob-node-1.title: Identifying Probability Experiments
learningFocus: Understand that probability experiments have uncertain outcomes
Identify when an outcome depends on chance
Distinguish probability experiments from deterministic processes

exemplarProblems.problemText: Which of the following is a probability experiment? (a) Tossing a coin to decide who goes first, (b) Calculating 12 × 8
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: (a) Tossing a coin - the outcome depends on chance and cannot be predicted with certainty. (b) is not a probability experiment because 12 × 8 always equals 96 (deterministic).

exemplarProblems.problemText: Explain why rolling a die is a probability experiment.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Rolling a die is a probability experiment because the outcome (which number lands face up) depends on chance and cannot be predicted with certainty before the die is rolled.

probabilityExperiments: Drawing a card from a shuffled deck
Drawing a ball from a bag
notProbabilityExperiments: Finding the area of a rectangle with known dimensions
Determining if 15 is odd or even

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question asking to identify OR explain probability experiment
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool - this is about conceptual understanding
Mix identification questions with explanation questions
Use contexts students encounter: coins, dice, cards, weather, sports
Emphasize KEY IDEA: outcome cannot be predicted with certainty (depends on chance)
Contrast with deterministic processes (calculations, measurements of fixed quantities)
Students should articulate WHY something is/isn't a probability experiment

prob-node-2.title: Listing Simple Sample Spaces
learningFocus: List ALL possible outcomes (complete sample space)
Use correct set notation with braces { }
State n(S) = total number of possible outcomes

exemplarProblems.problemText: A die is rolled. Write down the sample space and state the total number of possible outcomes.
A spinner is divided into five equal sectors of different colors: red, orange, blue, green, purple. Write down the sample space and state n(S).
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: S = {Red, Orange, Blue, Green, Purple}, n(S) = 5

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question - list sample space and state n(S)
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool initially - students should write it themselves
Use simple experiments: coin toss, die roll, spinner with named sectors
Require BOTH sample space in set notation AND n(S) value
Emphasize completeness: ALL outcomes must be listed
Use braces { } for set notation
Vary spinner colors and number of sectors (4-6 sectors)

prob-node-3.title: Listing Sample Spaces with Distinct Objects
learningFocus: Use subscripts to distinguish identical-looking objects (B₁, B₂, W₁, W₂, W₃)
Recognize that visually identical objects are distinct outcomes
List sample space correctly with subscript notation

exemplarProblems.problemText: A bag contains two identical black balls and three identical white balls. One ball is drawn at random. Write down the sample space and state the total number of possible outcomes.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: S = {B₁, B₂, W₁, W₂, W₃}, n(S) = 5 (using subscripts to distinguish the balls)

exemplarProblems.problemText: A bag contains 5 identical blue marbles and 4 identical red marbles. One marble is drawn. State n(S).
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: n(S) = 9 (the marbles are distinct even though they look identical within each color)

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question about drawing from bag with identical-looking objects
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Emphasize using subscripts: B₁, B₂ for black balls; W₁, W₂, W₃ for white balls
Students must understand that identical-looking objects are still DISTINCT outcomes
Question can ask for full sample space OR just n(S)
Use 2-3 objects per color, total 5-9 objects maximum
Accept answer with or without explicit subscripts IF n(S) is correct

prob-node-4.title: Listing Large Sample Spaces with Ellipsis
learningFocus: Use ellipsis (...) for long lists
Calculate n(S) arithmetically without listing all outcomes
Handle consecutive integers efficiently

exemplarProblems.problemText: A two-digit number is chosen at random. Write down the sample space using ellipsis and state the total number of possible outcomes.
Ten identical cards numbered 11, 12, 13, ..., 20 are placed in a box. One card is drawn at random. Write down the sample space and state n(S).

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question for large sample spaces
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Use ellipsis notation: {10, 11, 12, ..., 99}
Students should calculate n(S) arithmetically, not by listing all outcomes
For consecutive integers from a to b: n(S) = b - a + 1
Common scenarios: two-digit numbers (90), numbered cards, receipt numbers
Emphasize efficient counting over explicit listing

prob-node-5.title: Understanding Equally Likely Outcomes
learningFocus: Understand 'equally likely' means each outcome has the same chance
Identify fair/unbiased experiments
Recognize probability scale: 0 ≤ P(E) ≤ 1

exemplarProblems.problemText: Are the outcomes equally likely when you toss a fair coin? Explain.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Yes, when tossing a fair coin, Head and Tail are equally likely because each outcome has the same chance of occurring (50%).

exemplarProblems.problemText: Can a probability be 1.5? Why or why not?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: No, probability must be between 0 and 1 inclusive (0 ≤ P(E) ≤ 1). A value of 1.5 is greater than 1, so it cannot be a valid probability.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question about equally likely outcomes OR probability scale
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool for conceptual questions
Questions about 'equally likely': fair coins, fair dice, equal spinner sectors
Questions about probability scale: Can P(E) be negative? Greater than 1?
Emphasize: 0 ≤ P(E) ≤ 1 for all events
P(E) = 0 means impossible, P(E) = 1 means certain
Students should explain reasoning, not just yes/no answers

prob-node-6.title: Calculating Simple Probabilities
learningFocus: Apply P(E) = n(E) / n(S)
Count favorable outcomes correctly
Simplify probability fractions

exemplarProblems.problemText: A die is rolled. Find the probability of getting: (i) a 5, (ii) an even number
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: (i) P(5) = 1/6, (ii) P(even) = 3/6 = 1/2 (favorable outcomes: 2, 4, 6)

exemplarProblems.problemText: A card is drawn from a box containing 12 cards numbered 1, 2, 3, ..., 12. Find P(drawing a perfect square).
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Perfect squares from 1-12: {1, 4, 9}. P(perfect square) = 3/12 = 1/4

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question with 1-2 parts asking for probabilities
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool - students should calculate
Use die rolls (n(S)=6) or numbered cards (n(S)=10 to 20)
Events: specific number, even/odd, prime, perfect square, greater than X
Students must: 1) Count favorable outcomes, 2) Apply formula, 3) Simplify fraction
Require simplified fractions (3/12 = 1/4)
Can ask for 2 parts if both use same sample space

prob-node-7.title: Probability with Numbered Balls
learningFocus: Calculate probabilities from bags with numbered objects
Handle ranges and conditions

exemplarProblems.problemText: A bag contains balls numbered 10, 11, 12, ..., 24. One ball is drawn. Find the probability of drawing: (i) a '21', (ii) an odd number, (iii) a prime number

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question with up to 3 parts
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Use consecutive numbered balls in a range
Events: specific number, odd/even, prime, multiples, perfect squares/cubes
Students must calculate n(S) from range, then count favorable outcomes
Ensure correct counting for each event type

prob-node-8.title: Playing Cards - Basic Probabilities
learningFocus: Understand standard deck: 52 cards, 4 suits, 13 ranks
Know 26 black (clubs, spades), 26 red (diamonds, hearts)
Calculate probabilities for suits, colors, ranks

exemplarProblems.problemText: A card is drawn from a standard pack of 52 playing cards. Find the probability of drawing: (i) a black card, (ii) a diamond

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question with 2-3 parts about basic card probabilities
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Use standard deck: 52 cards total
Events: black/red card, specific suit (diamond, heart, club, spade)
Students must know: 26 black, 26 red, 13 cards per suit
Require simplified fractions
Focus on basic events first before complex ones

prob-node-9.title: Playing Cards - Composite Events
learningFocus: Handle composite card events (red Ace, picture card)
Know picture cards: J, Q, K (12 total)
Use complementary counting when appropriate

exemplarProblems.problemText: A card is drawn from a standard pack. Find the probability of drawing: (i) a red Ace, (ii) a picture card, (iii) a card which is not a diamond
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: (i) P(red Ace) = 2/52 = 1/26 (Ace of hearts, Ace of diamonds), (ii) P(picture) = 12/52 = 3/13 (J,Q,K in each of 4 suits), (iii) P(not diamond) = 39/52 = 3/4

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question with 2-3 composite events
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Composite events: red Ace, black King, picture card (J,Q,K), not a suit
Picture cards: J, Q, K only (NOT Ace) = 12 total
For 'not X' events, use complement: P(not diamond) = 1 - P(diamond) OR count directly (39/52)
Students must carefully count composite conditions
Ensure simplified fractions

prob-node-10.title: Impossible and Certain Events
learningFocus: Identify impossible events: P(E) = 0 (no favorable outcomes)
Identify certain events: P(E) = 1 (all outcomes favorable)
Verify 0 ≤ P(E) ≤ 1

exemplarProblems.problemText: A die is rolled. Find P(rolling a 7). What type of event is this?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: P(rolling a 7) = 0/6 = 0. This is an impossible event because a standard die only shows 1-6.

exemplarProblems.problemText: Cards numbered 1-12 are in a box. Find P(drawing a number less than 20). What type of event is this?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: P(number < 20) = 12/12 = 1. This is a certain event because all cards satisfy the condition.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question about impossible OR certain event
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Impossible events: P(E) = 0 - no outcomes satisfy condition
Certain events: P(E) = 1 - all outcomes satisfy condition
Common impossible: rolling 7 on standard die, negative number from positive set
Common certain: rolling 1-6 on die, positive number from 1-12
Students should calculate probability AND identify event type
Emphasize: impossible ≠ unlikely (P=0 vs P close to 0)

prob-node-11.title: Understanding Experimental vs Theoretical
learningFocus: Define theoretical: calculated using P(E) = n(E)/n(S)
Define experimental: observed from actual trials (relative frequency)
Understand why experimental ≠ theoretical in small samples

exemplarProblems.problemText: What is the theoretical probability of getting a head when tossing a fair coin? If you toss the coin 20 times and get 12 heads, what is the experimental probability? Why are they different?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Theoretical: P(Head) = 1/2 = 0.5. Experimental: 12/20 = 0.6. They are different because experimental probability varies due to randomness in small samples. With only 20 tosses, we don't expect to get exactly 10 heads every time.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question comparing theoretical and experimental
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Provide: theoretical probability, experimental results (trials and successes)
Students should: 1) State theoretical, 2) Calculate experimental, 3) Explain difference
Key explanation: randomness causes variation in small samples
Emphasize: experimental ≠ theoretical is EXPECTED, not an error
Use realistic trial counts: 10-100 tosses/rolls

prob-node-12.title: Calculating Relative Frequency
learningFocus: Calculate relative frequency = occurrences / total trials
Express as fraction and decimal
Compare experimental with theoretical probability

exemplarProblems.problemText: A coin is tossed 50 times. Heads appears 28 times. Calculate the relative frequency of getting heads. Compare with theoretical probability.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Relative frequency = 28/50 = 0.56. Theoretical P(Head) = 1/2 = 0.5. The experimental result (0.56) is close to but not exactly equal to the theoretical value (0.5).

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question calculating relative frequency
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Formula: Relative frequency = (number of occurrences) / (total trials)
Provide experimental data: number of trials and number of successes
Students should calculate relative frequency AND compare with theoretical
Express as both fraction and decimal
Use realistic experiments: coin tosses (theoretical 0.5), die rolls (theoretical 0.167)

prob-node-13.title: Law of Large Numbers Intuition
learningFocus: Understand experimental approaches theoretical as trials increase
Recognize high variation in small samples
Explain why more trials give better estimates

exemplarProblems.problemText: If theoretical P(red) = 0.5, which is more reliable: experimental result from 20 trials or from 200 trials? Why?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: The result from 200 trials is more reliable because as the number of trials increases, the experimental probability approaches the theoretical probability. Larger samples have less random variation than small samples.

exemplarProblems.problemText: A student tosses a coin 10 times and gets 7 heads. They conclude the coin is unfair. What would you tell them?
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: 10 tosses is a very small sample. Due to randomness, it's normal to get 7 heads in 10 tosses even with a fair coin. To determine if the coin is truly unfair, they should conduct many more trials (hundreds or thousands). With a fair coin, experimental probability will approach 0.5 as trials increase.

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question about reliability OR convergence
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Key concepts: more trials → closer to theoretical, small samples → high variation
Question types: 1) Compare reliability of different sample sizes, 2) Explain unexpected small-sample results
Students should explain WHY large samples are better (less random variation)
Emphasize: experimental may NEVER exactly equal theoretical but gets arbitrarily close
Connect to real science: why experiments are repeated many times

prob-node-14.title: Probability Using Angles - Spinners
learningFocus: Recognize when outcomes are NOT equally likely (unequal sectors)
Apply P(sector) = (angle of sector) / 360°
Convert angle measurements to probability fractions

exemplarProblems.problemText: A spinner is divided into sectors with angles: Red (90°), Blue (45°), Green (180°), Pink (45°). Find the probability that the spinner lands on: (i) red, (ii) green

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question with 2-3 parts about spinner with UNEQUAL sectors
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Formula: P(sector) = (angle of sector) / 360°
Provide angles for each sector (must sum to 360°)
Emphasize: outcomes are NOT equally likely because sectors have different sizes
Students should: 1) Use angle ratio formula, 2) Simplify fractions
Verify all sector probabilities sum to 1
Use 3-5 sectors with angles that give nice fractions (90°, 60°, 120°, 180°, 45°)

prob-node-15.title: Complementary Events
learningFocus: Understand P(not E) = all outcomes except E
Apply P(not E) = 1 - P(E)
Verify P(E) + P(not E) = 1

exemplarProblems.problemText: A card is drawn from a standard deck. P(diamond) = 1/4. Find P(not diamond) using: (i) the complementary formula, (ii) direct counting. Verify both methods give the same answer.
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: (i) P(not diamond) = 1 - P(diamond) = 1 - 1/4 = 3/4. (ii) There are 39 cards that are not diamonds (52 - 13 = 39), so P(not diamond) = 39/52 = 3/4. Both methods give 3/4 ✓

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question finding complement using BOTH methods
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Provide P(E) and ask for P(not E)
Students should use BOTH: 1) Complement formula P(not E) = 1 - P(E), 2) Direct counting
Verify both methods give same answer
Emphasize: P(E) + P(not E) = 1 always
Use simple events: specific suit, color, die outcome

prob-node-16.title: When to Use Complement Method
learningFocus: Recognize when complement method is more efficient
Choose between complement and direct counting

exemplarProblems.problemText: A die is rolled. Find P(not getting a 6) using the complement method.
In a bag of 20 marbles (5 red, 15 blue), find P(not red).
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: P(not red) = 1 - P(red) = 1 - 5/20 = 1 - 1/4 = 3/4 OR directly: P(blue) = 15/20 = 3/4

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question using complement method
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Ask for P(not E) explicitly
Students should apply: P(not E) = 1 - P(E)
Scenarios where complement is efficient: 'not X' where X is simple to calculate
Can also ask which method (complement vs direct) student prefers and why

prob-node-17.title: Real-World Probability - Prize Wheels
learningFocus: Apply probability to real contexts (shopping, games)
Handle equal and unequal sectors
Interpret probability in decision-making

exemplarProblems.problemText: A shopping mall prize wheel is divided into 6 equal sectors with prizes: $30, $50, $60, umbrella, $40, cheesecake. Find the probability that a customer wins: (i) an umbrella, (ii) a cash voucher
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: (i) P(umbrella) = 1/6 (one sector out of 6 equal sectors). (ii) P(cash voucher) = 4/6 = 2/3 (four sectors have cash: $30, $50, $60, $40)

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question with 2-3 parts about real-world scenario
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Contexts: shopping prize wheels, board game spinners, lottery scenarios
Can use equal sectors (count favorable) OR unequal sectors (use angles)
Events: specific prize, category of prizes (all cash, all physical items)
Students should: 1) Identify favorable outcomes, 2) Calculate probability, 3) Simplify
Make context engaging and realistic

prob-node-18.title: Real-World - Biased Experiments
learningFocus: Handle non-equally likely outcomes (biased dice, weighted experiments)
Given probabilities for some outcomes, find others
Use fact that all probabilities sum to 1

exemplarProblems.problemText: A biased die is rolled. The probability of rolling each number is: P(1) = 0.1, P(2) = 0.15, P(3) = 0.2, P(4) = 0.25, P(5) = 0.2. Find P(6).
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: Since all probabilities must sum to 1: P(1) + P(2) + P(3) + P(4) + P(5) + P(6) = 1. Therefore: 0.1 + 0.15 + 0.2 + 0.25 + 0.2 + P(6) = 1, which gives 0.9 + P(6) = 1, so P(6) = 1 - 0.9 = 0.1

exemplarProblems.problemText: A spinner is weighted so that P(Red) = 0.4 and P(Blue) = 0.35. The only other color is Green. Find P(Green).
exemplarProblems.correctAnswer: P(Red) + P(Blue) + P(Green) = 1. Therefore: 0.4 + 0.35 + P(Green) = 1, which gives 0.75 + P(Green) = 1, so P(Green) = 1 - 0.75 = 0.25

generationGuidelines: GROUND RULE: Generate ONE question about biased/weighted experiment
CRITICAL: DO NOT include mathTool
Key principle: All probabilities must sum to 1
Provide probabilities for some outcomes, ask student to find missing probability
Context: biased dice, weighted spinners, loaded coins
Students should: 1) Add given probabilities, 2) Subtract from 1 to find missing
Use decimal probabilities (clearer for biased experiments)
Verify all provided probabilities are valid (0 ≤ P ≤ 1) and sum < 1
